case_vignette: A 70-year-old female with past medical history of end stage renal disease on hemodialysis, coronary artery disease presents to dermatology clinic complaining of a painful rash on the right leg present for several weeks and enlargening. She admits she often misses hemodialysis sessions. Examination of the right lower leg demonstrates a retiform violaceous plaque with large black eschar. A punch biopsy reveals calcification of small and medium sized vessels with thrombosis.  The patient is diagnosed with calciphylaxis.  The patient is advised to attend all hemodialysis sessions and to take calcium and phosphorus binders as prescribed.  The patient is also advised to elevate the affected leg and to avoid tight clothing that may cause friction.  The patient is also advised to avoid smoking and to limit alcohol consumption.  The patient is also advised to follow a low salt diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low fat diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low sugar diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low cholesterol diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low phosphorus diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low protein diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low sodium diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low potassium diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low calcium diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low fat diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low sugar diet.  The patient is also advised to follow a low cholesterol diet.
